element_texts.text:
Holabird Library 
Memorial Collection
Fort Sheridan, Illinois
Journal showing the Route taken by the Government Train accompanying the 15th Rgt: US Infantry From Austin Tex To Ft. Craig N.M. and returning To San Antonio July - December 1869.
Prepared under direction of Brvt. Lt. Col.
Thos. B. Hunt
A. Q. M.     U. S. A.

Remarks. 
_____________________________________________________
Open uncultivated country, covered with brush. timber, no houses. 
Poor looking country, covered with stunted oak and brush, no houses, road good. - The ravine contains water.

Crossing of stream good. 

Desolate looking country. 
Country rolling with the exception of sandy and loamy flats to the right of the road. 
_____________________________________________________
Good water in Williams - Creek, crossing good; The road runs through a hilly limestone country, poor loamy soil, oaktimber, very few houses; - grazing fair. Driver Heckman was ran over by the blacksmith wagon, will probably die. Halt for water, fine pool to the left of the road. The country is limestoned, poor and hilly all along. 
_________________________________________________________
Crossing of train from Austin over the Colorado river to Camp near Barton Creek, a place 1 mile from the river. Ford deep, current strong, bottom sandy. Camp on flat ground. —

Date. Hour. Weather. Dist. Route. 
July 23. 9.15 8.15 7.10 6.05 5.35 a.m. cloudy and damp 15.97 2.50 2.50 2.95 1.05 Carried image--map of path Small Creek Running Brook Ravine Good Stream Fields Pool Brook High Limestone Ridge Small Stream Fine Cotton & Corn 
July 22. 9.35 8. 6.30 a.m clear shower of rain. 2.97 3. image--map of path Camp No 2 Williams Creek S.E. Pool 
July 21. clear 1. image--map of path Camp no 1 Creek Bartens? Spring Ford Colorado River. AUSTIN CITY THE NEWBERRY LIBRARY Ayer MS 3098 map map sh: 4031. P2 1869. B8

Remarks. 
________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Rest (Sunday). 
_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Descended a very rough & rocky hill to Millers Creek. Crossing very rough and crooked; the creekbed is solid rock, strong current of clear cold water, 1 foot deep, 100 feet wide. Beautiful campground on bluff near bank of creek, 1/2 mile from it are 2 houses, 1/4 mile distant a grave of Mr. and Mrs. Phelps, who were killed by Indians yesterday and buried to day. — Grazing is poor. 
Middle Creek is 50 feet wide, 1 foot deep, edges & bed very rocky, crossing very rough. At Phelps' place near the Creek 17 Indians were seen last evening. 
Yagers Creek 50 feet wide, 6 inches deep, banks 10 feet high, fall to the right of the road 10 feet limestone bottom, crossing good. There is a bad place in the road, before arriving at Yagers Creek, had to be repaired, before wagons could cross. 
Flat Creek is 50 feet wide, 6 inches deep, banks 10 feet high ; to the right of the road a fall of 10 feet; crossing swampy and boggy. 
The hill to the left of the road is high, looks like an earthwork. The road is very rough and rocky, land limestone, covered with shruboak, no houses. The crossing of the 4 small streams is bad. 
___________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Road rough, mostly limestone. 
The ravine contains water and has very rough ridges on both sides. — Beyond the ravine is a high prairie covered with brush. 
The hill to the left of the farm- house is very high. Grazing fair. Bear Creek is 50 feet wide, 6 inches deep, banks 10 feet high, bottom limestone, crossing good; a fall of 10 feet to the right of the road. —

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route. 
July 25. cloudy 42.44 Carried image--map 
July 24. 1.35 p.m. 1.84 12.45 0.75 12. 3.50 cloudy 10.15 11.60 9.20 7.40 5.30 a.m 
July 23 (continued). 1.30 p.m 4.55 cloudy and damp. 12.15 2.23 10. 1. 1. 15.97 Brought forward

Remarks. 
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Road and country have been improving since going to the river; the country is covered with post-oak timber, mostly of large growth. — Grazing fair. — Indians were here yesterday stealing stock. 
Pedernales river is 100 feet wide, 3 feet deep, crossing good. 
Three miles from Grape Creek the road passes a lake 200 yards wide, within 50 yards from the road; — and 2 miles from Grape Creek it runs within 200 yards of the river. 
The country is well timbered, roads good. 
Grape Creek is 40 feet wide, 1 1/2 foot deep, good crossing, gravel bottom, road good. 
Creek 10 feet wide, 1 foot deep; very bad crossing for wagons. 
Two miles from Williamson's Creek the road runs near the Pedernales river and keeps along its bank for 13 miles; — country heavily timbered. 
Williamsons Creek is 40 feet wide and 2 feet deep, crossing good. Rolling country and good roads, grazing good; low post-oak through the country. — 
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________
The road has been very rough and heavy in some places, 7 wagons stalled, 2 were upset; passed several houses and cornfields.— Grazing and water good, wood scarce. Limestone lies deeper, appearing only in bed of streams. Rocky Creek is 50 feet wide, 15 inches deep. 
Crossing of Flat Creek No. 2. swampy and boggy on banks, but its bed is solid limestone. 
The country rises continually to a high ridge; the road is most of the way good, but rocky in some places and swampy and boggy in others. The crossing of the small brooks is bad. 
The road runs into Millers Creek and up the bed about 1000 yards, then up a steep boggy bank;— road boggy for about 1/2 mile. The wagons went off the road through a cornfield; passed several boggy holes.— Millers, Middle & Yagers Creek, all evidently flow into the Pedernales river.

Remarks.
________________________________________________________________________________
At Camp no wood but low bushes; water good, grazing poor.  Open rolling rough country, rough roads, limestone rock ledges.
Very bad hill 2 miles from Camp.
High ridge, divided. The open timber, with which the country was covered ends here.
Road good; the crossing of the three small streams good.
________________________________________________________________________________
Roads good, country hilly, grazing poor.
Friedericksburg is a German Settlement of about 2000 inhabitants with five schools, several large mills and a variety of mechanics; very few if any freedmen.  A good deal of wheat is grown in this neighborhood.
The Creek is 10 feet wide, 6 inches deep, crossing good.  
After passing the Fort we crossed a creek of 50 feet wide and 6 inches deep, crossing good.
Old Fart "Martin Scott" is a ruin, all but one house, used as a warehouse.

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route. 
97.02 Carried 
July 29. 11.30 10. 7.45 6.15. clear 3.50 5.26 4.50 image--map of route taken Brook Camp No 8 Cherry Springs Brook Brook S.W. S.W. Stream Brook Brook Stream
July 28. 9.55 a.m. 7.40 7. 6.40 6.10 cloudy 3.08 2. 0.50 2.45 image--map of route taken Corn Fields Creek Camp No 7 Fiedericksburg Creek Creek S.E. Old Fort Martin Scott 75.73 Brought forward

Remarks.
_____________________________________________________________________________________
A splendid spring at Form Mason, 6 inches deep. Sandstone through the country, post-oak and willows.
Roads good.
_____________________________________________________________________________________
Rest (Sunday)
_____________________________________________________________________________________
This ford is known as the "Fort Mason Crossing" on the regular mail-route; it is a very uncertain, 6 inches deeper would have made it dangerous.  Large rocks in the channel had to be removed before the train could cross.-  The 2 islands form 3 branches, strong current about 10 miles an hour; depth of first branch 2  1/2 feet, of the 2d and 3d 3 and 3 1/2 feet. Grazing good, plenty wood; each channel of river is about 100 feet wide.-
_____________________________________________________________________________________
Camped South of Llano-river on a hill, which is steep toward the river, but good; large trees on the banks of the river.
Beaver Creeks is 100 feet wide, 1 foot deep; crossing good.
Very pretty post-oak country all day, road excellent.
The appearance of the rock has changed some, ragged knobs of sandstone showing quite often.  Beds of streams are still limestone.
Open post-oak country, farms on the right and left of road.
Road good.-

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route 
121.78 Carried 
August 2. 10.15 6.05 clear 6.37 image--map of route taken Fort Mason (abandon'd) Post? Spring Corn SE Brook Comanche Cr: Comanche Cr: S 
August 1. clear. 
July 31. 10 a.m 6.30 clear 1.63 image--map of route taken Camp No 10 Mail Station Store (Martins) B.B? & W.W. Shop. Farm Island Island Llano River N.E 
July 30. 1.35 p.m. 12.40 7.20 6. a.m clear 2.50 8.76 5.50 image--map of route taken Camp No 9 Beaver Cr. E Store (Mouseback)  Grave with heavy Stonewall E E Farm Farms 97.02 Brought forward

Remarks.
_____________________________________________________________________________________________
Camp on a plain, covered with prairie dog-holes, grazing fair, plenty of wood; roads good with the exception of a very bad place beyond the brook and of the crossing of the brook.
San Saba river is 60 feet wide, 2 feet deep, crossing good.
Mail-Station at Taylors Ranch.
The pool of water is not permanent. - The 3 crossings are very bad, swampy.
To the left of road is valley, on the right table-lands.
A beautiful large spring out of solid limestone rock on left of road; post oak and mequite in the valley.
Stream very small, nearly dry.- Road good, passes between hills, (high divide, 200 feet high) and along the side of a ridge to the right of a wide valley, covered with mesquite and post-oak.  Sandstone with indications of iron.
_________________________________________________________________________________________________
Water in Honey Creek only in Holes of rocks in its bed, but it is running in winter. Grazing fair.
A very curious hill of ragged sandstone all bare, to the left of road.  The country is covered with post oak and mesquite.
In front of the store and mail station is a well 40 feet deep of never failing water; a B. S. near it, and a W. W., Shop 1/2 mile to the right of it.

Date. Hour. Weather. Dist. Route 
148.25 Carried 
August 3. 3.45 1.55 p.m 11.05 8.30 7.20 6.05 clear, very heavy dew during night. 2. 9 2.50 3.50 3.47 image--map of route taken Camp No 12 San Saba River Brook Taylor? Pool of Water Swampy RIverlet? Brook Brook Rock Spring S.W. 
August 2. (continued) 1.35 p.m 10.25 clear 5.50 0.50  image--map of route taken Camp No 11 Honor? Creek Brook Brook Big Ravine Ho. W.W. Shop. Houses W.W. Store (Lockhardt) 121.75 Brought forward

Remarks
Lipan Springs run out from under solid rock and sink into the ground about 1 mile from the source. The country becomes gradually more barren; level prairie covered with mesquite brush and some sage; prickly pear and cactus increasing in size and quantity. Grazing good, road excellent, no water near it. Saw some antelopes. 
Kickapoo springs run out from under a solid limestone rock, forming at once a Creek 60 feet wide and 1 1/2 foot deep. A company of colored troops is stationed here to protect the mail station. Grazing good, water clear and cold. The country looks very pleasant. 
The roads are good to day but devoid of water, except the pools. There is a pool of water at the bottom of a limestone ridge. The Waterhole is not permanent. 
Road good, ledge of rock to the right and a pool of water in a Rock to the left. 
Grazing fair, no water except in the river. The country has a very pretty appearance; road good, ground stony after crossing the stream. Hills to the left of river low. 
Crossing of San Saba River good, 1 foot deep, falls small.
Creek 1 foot deep, crossing good. 
Excellent road through a broad valley, covered with small timber and mesquite. Range of low limestone hills to the left of road. 
San Saba river is 50 feet wide, good crossing, easy banks. 
Road good, over prairie. 
Pool of water not permanent, prairie covered with scrub bushes.

Date. Hour. Weather Dist: Route. August 6. 10. 5.55 a.m clear & hot cold night 198.26 9.45 image--map of path Lipan Springs Do? Longs Ranch Camp No 15 August 5. 5 p.m 3.35 1 p.m 10.30 6.30 5.50 a.m. clear, good breeze night and morning cold, hot during the day. 2.59 5.30 5.60 9.40 2. image--map of path Mail Station (Flanigan) Camp No 14 Creek Camp unclear Springs color'd Troops Pool Waterhole Pool of Water in Rock 18 Miles to Fort M? unclear August 4. 12.40 p.m. 11.45 7.55 7.10 6.07. clear very heavy dew during the night. 1.67 9. 1.83 3.17 image--map of path Camp No 13 Mail St. (Coglin) Small Stream Falls Lake Creek San Saba River Pool 148.25 Brought forward

Immense quantities of buffalo-chips; good grass, wood and water. At 1/2 mile from Camp the road approaches the river within 100 yards.
Road good, river 15 feet wide, 1 foot deep.
Signal Station for surveying. 
Road good.
Fine spring, road good. The Camp is known as "Kelley's Camp", Major Kelley having died at this place. 
Good spring, 3/4 mile left of road. 
Spring small. We passed on the road 3 small pools of water, about equal distance, but it was only fit for stock. 
Timber, mostly pecan, is only found on the river bank; the country, prairie as well as mountains, is perfectly bare of it, except mesquite bushes. Grass good, road good, describes nearly  3/4 of a circle around the Twin Mountains. We got on a wrong road here for about 2 1/2 miles; the new road runs to the right of Twin Mountains, the old untravelled one to the left. 
Prairie country, good road; beautiful view of wide but sterile plain and low mountains in the distance. 
At Concho (Consolidation)
Fort Concho is intended for an 8 Comp'y Post, but not completed; the buildings are of stone, quarters and hospital very fine. It is situated on an open plain in fork of Concho river, the banks of which are lined with pecan trees (mostly very large); these trees furnish the wood for fuel. Grazing fair.
There is no water between the Waterhole and Concho river. 
Road through a level prairie, mountains in a distance.

Date                                                  Hour               Weather        Dist.                               Route
                                                                                                     251.64                    Carried
                                                        
                                                         2.35 pm                                  2.50

                                                         1.05                                        5.67

                                                        10.20                                       5.86

                                                          7.50                                       3.14
                                                          7.                                           1

August 20                                          6.15

                                                         3.50 pm                                 13.26

                                                       10.30                                          3,20                                           (Image of map)

August 19                                          8.35
August 8-18 incl.

                                                         1 p.m.                                      9.25



                                                       9.25                                          9.50

August 7.                                         5.55

                                                                                                      198.26         Brought forward

Remarks
Water only temporary, there was enough though for command of  350 men and about 450 mules, quite good for drinking. No wood, grazing poor.
Good water most of the year, was fit to drink. Roads good, thick mesquite and fair grass.
Water only fit for animals
Old Mail Station is abandoned
Pool of water small, not permanent.
Rest (Sunday)
The 'Concho' river heads in a plain 3 miles wide, surrounded on all sides but one by low aird hills, destitute of all timer. The plain is perfectly dry and dusty but has fine grass (the general character of the country to this place) The river evidently arises from springs, as there is absolutely no surface water here, except from rains in fall and winter. An old stone breastwork, and abandoned house to the left of camp. We say 10 Indians at a great distance off. Wood scare at camp. -
Old Camp Charlotte is an abandoned Cavalry camp.
Road rough and rocky.

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route August 23. 11. p.m 2. p.m 12.20 11.15 9.50 clear. 296.97 Carried 13.50 5.50 2.40 3.80 image--map of path Flat Rock Waterholes Camp No 20 Slustang? Waterholes Pool Old Mail St. Pool August 22. clear. August 21. 2.35 p.m 1.15 10.40 10.05 6.15 clear 3.13 5 1.50 2.50 8  image--map of path Shallinburger's? Head Waters Mail St Old St. Camp No 19 Kiowa Creek CAMP CHARLOTTE Spring Large Pool 251.64. Brought forward

Remarks
This day we spent in crossing. Stores etc. were put on rafts, made of ((4)) watertanks. Wagons and mules, the latter swimming, were hauled across the ford on the rope. Time of crossing between 12 m. and 9 p.m. - The river runs through a plain about 30 miles wide and can not be seen until arrived on its banks; no timber near it. The crossing at the Ford is rather risky.
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Pecos  river is about 40 feet wide, 4 1/2 feet deep, banks 10 feet high, bottom quicksand, current rapid, water muddy and strong with alkaline. Grass is abundant, but the animals do not seem to like it; wood scarce.
The road from the Canon is about 2 miles long, very rough and rugged with a few alkaline waterholes and full of dead cattle, the water is totally unfit to drink for man and beast. It contains a great variety of beautiful wild flowers.
The road to the Canon runs over what is know as "Staked Plains", covered with nothing but Spanish bayonet and low bushes the fruit of the former looks like banana and tastes like baked apple, full off hard black seed.
Roads good.
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Good water for men and animals; grazing poor, no wood  but green mesquite.
Water was issued to day from the tanks to the men twice.
The mail road forks off to the left, goes to the lower crossing of Pecos river and joins again at Fort Stockton.
A detachment of colored troops is stationed here; the water for the use of these men is hauled from the of Concho, a didstance of 32 miles.
Road good, the country is a dry desert.

Date Hour Weather Dist Route
August 26 9. p.m 12. m clear 350.47 Carried map including the words: Camp No. 25, Horsehead Cross'g, Old Station, Ferry and Pecos River
August 25 5.30 p.m 2. 9.30 6.45 clear 12.58 8.11 6.50 map including: Camp No 22, Castle mts, Staked Plains
August 24. 7.30 p.m. 9 6.50 clear 20.58 6. 296.97 Brought forward map including: Wild China, Camp No 21, Nail Roudm Middle Mail St

Remarks
Leon Holes are 24 feet deep, water permanent, clear but brackish sinks away in about 1 1/2 mile from here.
The road is good, though very heave in wet weather for the last 5 miles, and wagons then take the road to the left, which runs along the foot of a little rising of ground. -
The country is covered with mesquite bush.
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Rest
Fort Stockton is only partially but so far well built, adobe with shingle roofs. _ The water of Comanche springs are alkaline, but clear, cold & good for drinking._ It is after passing the fort, used for irrigating the post garden, about 4 miles from the fort, when it flows off towards the Pecos and sinks away in the desert. _
The mail road goes to the lower crossing of Pecos river.
The country around Fort is level; mountains at a distance.
Roads good, grazing fair, wood scarce, mesquite wood being used as firewood by the Government.
______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Beautiful permanent springs, but very strong with alkaline; grass the same. Road good, travelled all day over a broad desert with mesquite about a knee high, the roots of which are used for firewood.

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route
Septembr. 2. 12. m 6.05 clear 395.46 5. 5.97 Carried map
August 29 to Septembr. 1.
August 28. 11.20 6.40 clear 10.41 map
August 27. 6.45 5.50 p.m. 7.30 a.m. clear 3 20.34 350.74 map Brought forward

Remarks
The road runs through a broad valley covered with good grass. An old camp road runs to the right of mountains toward the spring joining the main road again, where the latter turns to the left up Lympia Canon. the Limpia River sinks away to the right of road. A spring of splendid water by the large rock to the right, grass good, roads heavy from recent rains.-
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Barilla springs would afford any quantity of good clear water if a tank was placed to catch it. Beside the well, which is 20 feet deep, there is a hole of rainwater near the Station. The Camp is 1/2 mile fro Main station; the road is rough and hilly, runs through a broad valley with hills on all sides.
We found no water of any account at McCombs springs; the road to it went up an untravelled valley between hills and mountains.
Here we turned to the right of main road, as Genl. Shepherd expected to find plenty of water in McCombs springs.
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Camp on hillside, grazing good, no wood; a high mountain about w miles to the right. There was water in Hackberry holes for men and animals._ the road descends from 9 mile holes to this place and is excellent, except some small boulders in it.
The small Waterholes are not permanent & the water only fit for stock (rain-water).- Grazing good, no wood. - Road good, though rough in places, through a desert, covered with mesquite.

Date Hour. Weather Dist. Route
Septembr. 5. 10.05 7.10 clear hard rain in the afternoon 440. go 8.64 Carried map including words Mouth of and Fine Spring Rock
Septembr. 4. 3.05 1.45 p.m 8.40 7.05 Rain commenced at 2 o'clock p.m. and continued all day. 4. 7.07 4. map including Camp No 28, Barilla Springs, McCombs Spring
Septembr. 3. 4. p.m 11.15 7 a.m clear very hard rain, thunder & hailstorm from 1.30 to 3 p.m. Brought forward map including Hackberry Holes, Camp No 27, Waterholes

Remarks
Rest
Fort Davis is intended for a 6 Company Post.  The officers quarters are built of red and white sandstone, other buildings adobe and partially unfinished.  Wood is scarce, grazing fair.  The Lympia river starts about 20 miles above Fort Davis and ordinarily sinks at the Mail- station 3 miles below, leaving only waterholes in the Canon; in rainy seasons through it runs all through it.
The road crosses Lympia-river 23 times and is very rough.  The river is about 2 1/2 feet deep and from 10 to 40 feet wide.  A red sandstone forms the walls of the narrow Canon, which are from 150 to 300 feet high and in many places perfectly perpendicular.
The road passes over a large steep hill before entering in the narrow part of the Canon.
__________________________________________________________________________________
On account of the hard rain in the afternoon we had a very bad camp; wood was scarce, grass good.   To the right of the road are 2 high mountains, which can be seen from a long distance; - the road is level up to here, but heavy from recent rains.

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route 
Septembr. 7. Carried
Septembr 6. 2.30 p.m. 7 a.m. clear & cool, some rain in the evening 14.55 map including Camp No 30
Septembr. 5. (continued) 12 m. hard rain in the afternoon 4.12 440. go Brought forward map including Camp No 29

Remarks
______________________________________________________________________________
Camped in the Canon past the Dead Mans Hole.  got water out of a spring in the Side.  Canon beyond the Hole, sufficient for men and animals.  There is a Mail-station close to Dead-Mans Hole; in the latter was but little water.  The road up to the Canon runs to the right of main road, and in the morning of the 10th we had to retrace our road about 1 1/2 miles. -   No wood, good grazing.
There is a large prairie dog town at the dry Waterholes.  The country is a rolling prairie, road good, grass good.
The road branching to the right goes to the Fort Davis pinery.
_________________________________________________________________________________________________
The road turns to the right between 2 mountains.  There is a Mail-station at the mouth of Canon; - 3/4 mile above it is Barrel-spring, which would afford a good supply of water, if there were anything for it to run into, - it now runs a short distance and sinks into the ground.  Our stock was watered in the in the waterhole 2 miles beyond camp. - No wood, grazing fair.  The road to Barrel-spring runs through a descending Canon, in places very rough and hilly.  Several waterholes and live-oaks in the Canon and plenty of marbe in the hills.
Point of rocks is a mountain of bare white rocks with a good spring at the foot of it.- The road from Fort Davis to here runs over a rolling prairie with live-oaks in spots.  Grazing and wood fair.  A road to Presidio del Norte branches off to the left two miles beyond Fort Davis.

Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
Septembr. 9. 9. 7.05 499. og 10.37 5.50 Carried map including Camp No 32, Dead Mans Hole
Septembr. 8. 4.30 p.m. 11.45 7 a.m. 11.65 10. 2. 459.59 Brought forward map including Camp No 31, Paint of Rocks, Spring, Barrel Spring, To Presidie del Norte

Remarks
Old Van Horns Well was dug by Mayor Van Horn, U.S.A. about 25 years ago, and is not used now; the new one is about 25 feet deep and contains 2 feet water, which runs in as fast as taken out, but is at times nearly dry. There is a Waterhole in the Cañon which watered about half the mules, the other half were watered out of the well. 
Volcanic indications are here plentiful. The wood is scarce, the grazing fair. The road runs through a broad valley and is good. 
The waterhole, 3/4 of a mile to the left of the road on foot of a mound afforded water enough for the animals by using buckets.
Dry Camp. Water was issued from the tanks. There are waterholes near the mountains to the left, but, very little water in them, and that was only fit for stock; as it soon was stirred into a mudhole, but few of the mules got any water.
The water in holes is good and plenty, the grass good. The road is good; it runs through a prairie with mountains on each side.

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route. 
Septembr. 11. 2.35 p.m. 11.15 7.10 clear. 533.63 7. 7.28 Carried map including Van Horn's Wells, Camp No 34, Dogtown W.H.
Septembr 10. 3.10 p.m. 9.45 7.10 clear. 13.83 6.43 499.09 Brought forward map including Camp No 33, Low Bluff Range, Waterholes

Remarks
Dry Camp, grass poor, no wood but mesquite and that even scarce, no water.
Mountains at a distance to the right.
The Eagle Mountains are a large group between the road and the Rio Grande; they are of great hights, in fact the highest on the whole route.
The road is at first very rough, crossing a great many ravines; the last part of the road descends and is good after passing a ridge.
Eagle spring is of moderate capacity and the water must be carefully dipped up; it only supplied the men, the mules were driven back to the waterholes (7 miles on the road) in the morning. 
The road goes through a broad valley. There is a rivulet of fine water 4 miles from Eagle spring off the road around the mountains.
The waterholes contain plenty of good water, but are not permanent; the road is undulating and good. 
Before coming to the Waterholes, we passed between two mountains ("Torta").

Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route. 
Septembr. 13. 7.50 p.m 1.45 p.m cloudy, cold Norther 571.51 16.19 Carried map including Camp No 36, Eagle
Septembr. 12. 1.30 p.m. 12.25 7.15 cloudy & rainy 7.20 14.39 533.63 Brought forward map including Camp No 35, Waterholes, PORTA

Remarks
Camp near Camp Rice Mail Station. Had wood, grazing good. 
The roads run first through a flat prairie, then it is undulating and sandy; mesquite country.
Rest (at Fort Quitman).
Camp on the bank of the Rio Grande; the river is wide, flat, and muddy, the current slow and circling through a flat muddy bed. The banks and bottom are quicksand and the water can only be got at in places. There is wood and grazing. Fort Quitman is a very gloomy looking place, adobe houses. The road is undulating and sandy, hard pulling; mesquite brush. 
The road from the Cañon to the river, where it turns to the right, is excellent with but one short steep hill 2 miles from the mouth of Cañon. Grazing is fine.
The Cañon is 4 miles long, very rough & dangerous on account of the Indians; its descent is very rapid. From Eagle Springs the land descends all the way to the Rio Grande; the climate here being so much warmer, the descent in 40 miles may be at least 2,500 feet.

Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
Septembr. 16. 2.10 p.m. 6.40. clear. 610.64 15.79 Carried map including Camp No 38, Camp Rice Stage Stand, Road to Salt Lake
Septembr. 15. clear
Septembr. 14. 5.50 7.10 clear & cold. 1. 7. 7. 8.44. 571.41 Brought forward map including Rio Grande (Mexico), Old Mail St. Houses, Camp No 37., FT QUITMAN

Remarks
The river at this place is dangerous on account of quicksand; there is timber on the banks of it.
The grazing is poor, the road heavy. 
San Elizario is a Mexican adobe town of about 600 inhabitants, supported entirely by the irrigation of the land.
Several bad crossings over irrigation ditches (Sacra's).
The road runs through a bottom, which in wet weather is very bad; on leaving the Mail station, a road therefore turns to the right around the high land. 
There is timber near the Mail station; the latter is abandoned; plenty of wood & water, but no grazing. 
The road is heavy, very sandy.
There was water in the large Holes, but it is not permanent; wood, but no grazing. The roads are heavy; the river is fordable here. 
The roads are heavy and undulating; mesquite trees are growing along the road. 
San Ignacio, on the Mexican side of the river, is a small place, the houses are built of adobe.
The grazing is fair, wood & water.

38
Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route
Septembr. 18. 3.45 2.45 p.m. 11.05 8. 6.50 clear 651.79 2. 10.50 8.30 3.70 Carried map including words Camp No 40, San Elizario, Rio Grande, Tora Mail Station
Septembr. 17. 12.55 6.35 clear 2. 14.65 610.64 Brought forward map including words Camp No 39, SAN IGNAZIO, Pierpoints Ranch and Mail St

Remarks
The road to Hart's Mills goes along the river bank and over a good many hills, very rough.
El Paso has about 6000 inhabitants, is built of adobe and supported by irrigation. 
Franklin is a good sized florishing town, built of adobe 2 miles from Camp Concordia.
The road is sandy, the country cultivated.
Rest (at Fort Bliss).
Camped at Old Camp Concordia, one mile from Fort Bliss and two miles from Franklin; wood is scarce.
The grazing is fair on the hills back of Old Fort Bliss.
Fort Bliss is the neatest post on the entire line travelled, garrisoned by two Companies.
Companies "A." & "K" 35" Infantry were taken up here and consolidated with the 15" Infantry.
The road is very heavy, in some places undulating; crosses several irrigation ditches.
Isletta is inhabited by Mexicans; the roads are very sandy, crossed by irrigation ditches, no grazing. 
Small Mexican town; the roads are very heavy with sand.

40
Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route.
Septembr. 22. 8.35 7.20 clear. 1.50 2. map including words EL-PASO, FRANKLIN, Hart's Mills
Septembr. 20. 21. 
Septembr. 19. 1.15 p.m. 6.40 clear 1. 8.90 4.95 651.79 Brought forward map including words Isletta, Socorra, FORT BLISS, Camp No 41, Old Fort Camp Concordia

Remarks
Old Fort Fillmore used to be a very fine place, but was abandoned at the beginning of the war; the buildings are in ruins, two or three of them occupied by mexicans. _
The road is very dusty, sandy and? somewhat hilly.
Water in the waterholes, which are in a dry creek-bek.
Grazing very poor, rough salt-grass; wood scarce.
Camp near Cottonwood Forage Agency ( New-Mexico); there is wood, grazing fair and? water in the waterhole.
The first part of the road is good rough, the latter part good but dusty. _ Mesquite? country. _
The water is good, said to be permanent; no grazing of any account, Mesquite? country, undulating and in some places sandy. _
Camped near the river on the road, which branches to the left; the right hand road does not go near the water, but is the most direct one; _ roads good.
Road very rough over steep hills.
There used to be a road? around the hills close to the river, which was excellent, but about 300 yards of it are washed away.

42
Date. Hour. Weather Dist. Route 
Septembr. 24. 10.05 5.30 clear. 711.58 2.55 11.83 Carried map including words OLD FT FILLMORE , Stevenson's Ranch
Septembr 23. 1.30 p.m 7 a.m clear 13.02 3.77 map including words Cottonwood Ranch (in N.Mex.), Camp No 43, Rio Grande
Septembr. 22. (continued) 1.20 p.m 12 m. clear 2. 5.07 673.34 Brought forward map including words Camp No 42, Ranch Mail Station

Remarks.
Rest (at Fort Selden).
Fort Selden is a neat Post for Cary? B Inffry?; the surrounding country is rough. Our Camp was in the bottom between the Fort and the river. - The grazing in the bottom is poor, on the hills good; trees on the river-banks; the road is very hilly and sandy. The Fort lies on a U. I. reservation. Leesburg is a small place about 1 mile from the Fort straight across the river, which here forms a pretty narrow bend. The country is covered with mesquite brush. The road goes over ridges, outrunners of hills on the bank of river; - no grass.There are mountains to the right of the road, distant at least 12 miles; the road goes through a sandy bottom, evidently an old bed of the river, partly cultivated. - Dona Anov is a small adobe town in a well cultivated country valley. The roads are good, grazing scarce, some Cottonwood. Las Cruces is a flourishing Mexican town of large size, built of adobe.-
Camp in the bottom to the left of road; wood and water is scarce. The road to day was sandy and undulating, the country is covered with sandhills. Mesilla used to be on the Mexican side of the river, but its bed has changed, and the town is now in New-Mexico. The Mesilla valley is irrigated and produces excellent fruit of every variety; - the town is well built and does large business. - The silver mine to the right of the road is 15 miles from Old Fort Fillmore.

44
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route'
Septbr. 26-29. 736.17 Carried part of map
Septembr. 25. 2.55 p.m 7 a.m. clear. 0.94 5.84 3.24 4.34 1.50 3.73 map including words FT SELDEN, Camp No 45, Leesburg, Corner of Reservation, Rio Grande, To Fort Stanton, DonaAna, Fletchers Houses, Las Cruces, Irrigated Lands
Septembr 24. (continued). 12.25 clear. 5 711.58 Brought forward map including Mesilla, Camp No 44, Hacionda of Stevenons, Silver Mine

Remarks. 
The well at Alimen's or Martin's Mail station is 130 feet deep, all but 16 feet blasted through solid rock; yields now 200 gallons water per day. Grazing is good, fuel can be procured. The small waterholes to the right of the road are artificial and very small. The country is a broad, open plain. The road to Point of Rocks runs over a barren, sandy country, but is good. The waterholes are nearly dry. Road good. The water in the small waterholes is only fit for stock, not permanent; the road is good.
An excellent road over a barren plain. - Camp 2 miles from the main road and 2 miles from the river, near which is a steep rough bluff. To the right of the road is wide plain (about 20 miles wide) surrounded by mountains. The road passes over a sandy country and a very high, sandy hill. started with Hed. Qrs? and 2 Companies of 15 Infantry.-

46
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
October 1. 3.45 p.m 6.30 clear & cold.  773.17 12. 2.50 0.50 10. Carried map including words Camp No 47. Martin's or Aleman's Mail St, Aleman's Well, 300 yds, Rio Grande
Septembr. 30. 12. m. 8.15  cloudy clear. 7. 5. 736.17 Brought forward map including San Diego Crossing, Camp No 46, Corner of Reservation

Remarks. 
The river here is 150 yards wide and 3 feet deep; it has a steep bank on the East side, but is easily forded. The road is very sandy.
Parajei is a town of about 500 inhabitants, situated on a low bluff with a valley below, about 1 mile wide, finely irrigated. It is the Northern end of the Fornado de Muerto or 90 mile Desert. The bluff itself is very sandy. To the left of the road is a high range, to the right a broad open barren plain. Road excellent. At 11 o'clock water was issued to the men. The road from the Canon to the junction is good. From the camp the road goes through a very rough canon and after it joins the main road; the Canon is 4 miles long.The road from the Canon to the junction is good.-
Fort McRae is a "One Company Post" for Infantry; - the quarters are good. It has fine springwater, a little alkaline. The country around is very desolate, poor grazing. The Canon road is very rough, 3 1/2 miles long.
We left the main road and went to Fort McRae for water;- from head to mouth of Canon 3 1/2 miles, from the mouth to Fort McRae 1 1/2 mile. Crossed a broad prairie, road good.

48
Date. Hour. Weatr. Dist. Route
824.17 Carried 
October 4. 8.15 7 a.m. clear. 3.50
October 3. 6.15 p.m 9.1506.30 clear & cold. 10.50 14.50 6. 
October 2. 12.30 8. 6.10 clear & cold 5. 5.50 6. 773.17 Brought forward

Remarks.
Camp at Ranch and Waterhole, between Cottonwood Ranch and Franklin.
Camp at Stevensons Ranch. Water in the Waterholes.
Camp at Fletchers House.
Those parts of the train, which had been detached to Fort Craig and Fort Cummings, returned to Fort Selden, where the train itself had stopped during their absence. 
On the 22d October the whole train started from the Camp near Fort Selden and proceeded back on the very same road, we had come.
Fort Craig is a large Post; the buildings, which are constructed of adobe, are quite extensive and comfortable. It is situated about 500 yards from the Rio Grande; the surrounding country is very barren and sandy. Grazing poor, no timber. 
Coal, which is principally used as fuel, is procured at a coal-mine about 30 miles from the Post. 
On the N.W. side of the Fort are hills (table) about 50 feet high.

50

Remarks
Camped at Eagle Springs; the animals were driven for water to the rivulet 4 miles from camp.
Camped at the mouth of Cañon. (Dry Camp).
Laid over at Fort Quitman.
Camped at Fort Quitman.
Camped at "Camp Rice" Stage stand. 
Camped at Pierpoints Ranch.
Camped at Hawkins Old Mail Station.
Camped 2 miles North of San Elizario (former Camp No. 40).
Rest (at Old Fort Bliss.)
Camped at Old Fort Bliss.

Camp at waterholes, 9.73 miles West of Hackberry Holes (Dry Camps) Hackberry- Holes were dry also.
Camp at Barilla-springs. (Water only in spring).
Camp at  formed camp N: 29
Laid Over

Camp at Barrel-Springs (abundant water)

Remarks
The road is the same as yesterday, valleys between low flat hills covered with mesquite.
The last waters of Escondido are only waterholes in an otherwise dry watercourse.
Escondido spring is on the foot of a high table mountain; water and grazing good, wood scarce.
The road goes through mesquite valleys, the country being covered with low flat hills or mountains. 
The Escondido is no stream properly, but a dry watercourse with only a few places containing water at great intervals.
From Fort Stockton 9 wagons started for Concho with detached Comp'y "I" 38"Inftry., and upon recommendation of A.A.L.M. at Fort Stockton the rest of the train started via Fort Clark, there being not sufficient water on the Stocked Plains for so many animals. 
At Fort Stockton
Camp at Fort Stockton.
At 11 o'clock the animals were turned out at Leon Waterholes to graze and water, and hooked up again at 12 o'clock m.

56
Date. Hour. Weathr. Dist. Route
29. Carried
Novembr. 19. 7.45 6. a.m clear. 6. 
Novembr. 18. 2.15 1.05 p.m 5 a.m clear & cold 3.50 19.50 
Distance from Ft Stockton
November. 16. 17. Total 348.96 from Ft Selden to Ft Stockton
Novembr. 15. clear & warm 22.97 325.99 Brought forward 
map including words FT STOCKTON, To Horsehead Crossing, Mail Route, 1st Water on Escondido, Mail St, Camp No 20, Escondido Spring, Last Waters on Escondido

Remarks
At Horseshoe Bend the road leaves the river and runs to the right of a mountain. The road is hilly and in some places rough.
Old Camp Melbourne is abandoned; the country covered with mesquite.
2 1/2 miles from Camp the left fork of the road goes to the river which is a mile from the turning off point; the mail crosses the river here. We took the road along the bank of the river.
Camped on the bank of the river. The grazing on the hills is fair, the wood scarce, water brackish.
The road passes through a country the same as yesterday, mesquite bottom with hills or mountains rising from the plain in every direction. From Escondido the road is more gravelly, descending to the Pecos river.

58
Date. Hour. Weathr. Dist. Route.
53. Carried
Novembr. 20. 8.40 7.15 6.30 clear. 4.50 2.50 
Novembr. 19. (continued) 12. m. clear. 17. 29. Brought forward
map including words Rio Pecos, Horseshoe Bend, Mail Station, Old CAMP MELBOURNE, Old Mail St. Camp No 21, Camp Road, Mail Road

Remarks.

The bridge is guarded by a few soldiers; the old road runs 1 or 2 miles below the bridge to an old Ford.
Along the foot of the mountain the road is rough, until it comes to the river, where it runs along the bank, and to the bridge.
Pecos - spring contains clear pure water, the first since leaving Barrel - spring; it runs in a pretty large stream into the Pecos - river.
The road from the Riffles is rough and turns at the spring to the right around a mountain. The Riffles on Pecos are more like rapids; road high & good; grazing poor, the country having been burned.
Camped on a flat near the river and just above the Riffles on Pecos. The road runs along the river and was good to day, passing over mesquite flats; in wet weather though these flats must be bad for wagons
The grazing is poor, no wood, only mesquite roots, which are hard to dig. -

60
Date. Hour. Weathr. Dist. Route.
82.70 Carried
Novembr. 21. 10.45 8.30 5.15 a.m. clear. 4.65 12.50 0.45 
Novembr. 20. (continued). 12. clear. 3.90 8.20 53. Brought forward 
map including words Camp No 22, Riffles, Pecos Spring, Rio Pecos, Hut for Guards, Ford Bridge

Remarks.
Camped at a place known as Cedarbrake; there was some
water in the holes in bed of stream, though not enough
for animals.- Grazing good. the road is excellent, 
toward the last descending.-
Arrived on top of the Middle Hill, the road lies over
all the valleys and runs on a smooth surface, as level
as a floor.
The road from the Upper Hill joins the other one near
the top of the Middle Hill.
Since two miles from Camp the road runs through a
valley for 6 miles, when it branches; the left road goes
to the Upper Hill, which is very steep and the better for 
wagons travelling West; the right or Middle Hill road is
rough, but not so steep and mostly travelled by wagons 
going East.-
Two miles from Camp the road turns to the right, passes
over a hill, then follows a dry bed of stream. The 
road is good but hilly.-
Old Camp Lancaster is situated on the slope of the hill, 1/2 mile from
the Camp. Grazing is good, wood scarce.- The road branches, 
the left one is the wagon-road, the right one ascends Lancaster
or Lower Hill-road, but is impracticable for wagons, though
much shorter than the left one.
The country between Pecos-river and Grape or Liveoak 
Creek is rough, but otherwise good.-

62
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
101.52 Carried 
Novembr. 22. 3.35 p.m 11 a.m cloudy and cold. 4.14 2.28 6.20 2.
November 21. (continued) 12 m clear. 0.21 3.99 82.70 Brought forward
map including words Live Oak Creek, Camp No 23, Pecos River, OLD CAMP LANCASTER, Lower Hill, Middle Hill, Table Land, Upper Hill Road, Camp No 24, Waterholes

Remarks.
The road forks; the one to the left is the shorter, but 
the hill it passes down, is too steep for wagons; the
right one goes around the hill and is not very steep,
though rough.-
A rough road until it comes to a steep rough hill,
and then it passes over table-lands to a broken country.
The roads join here again; they are very rough.
Camped near the Forks; the left hand road is the shorter, 
but very rough; the train took the right hand road.
Howards Well is a h ole dug 8 feet deep in gravel in a 
dry creek-bed; the water is good. The animal water-
ed out of troughs and had plenty of water.-
Mesquite flat, grazing fair.
The roads are good except on some places, where
they are rough. To the hill it is 9.03 miles, when
it runs through a rough Cañon into a valley, 
where the road is far.
The hill is short and rough.-

64
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
131.52 Carried
Novembr 24. 1.40 p.m 10.45 clear & warm, cloudy. 1.50 1.35 6.08 1.24 
Novembr. 23. 11.45 8.30 5.30 clear & cold. 0.46 9.61 9.76 101.52 Brought forward 
map including words Old Mail Station, Howards Well, Camp No 25

The road to the Beaverlake camping ground turns to the left,
the one down the river to the right.
The first three crossings of Devils river are dry, the water
evidently running under ground; after that it becomes a run-
ning stream. The distance from the fork of road to Beaver-
lake is 1.95 miles.
The waterhole to the left of road is in a gourd (so called).
The road passes over two hills.
Grave of a Mexican, killed May 28, 1869, when a train 
of Adams & Wickes of San Antonio was surprised here
by Indians and 77 mules stolen by them.-

Dry Camp at the foot of a mound, which is some pro-
tection to stock, no wood nor water, road good.
Johnsons run is day; the grass has been burned all
over this part of the country; road good.
Waterhole on foot of a rock- bluff.-

66
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
162.65 Carried
Novembr. 25. 1. p.m 6.30 a.m cloudy drizling rain, rain cloudy. 1.95 6.85 8. map including words Camp No 27, Old Mail. St, BeaverLake, Grave, Saint Nina W.H., Camp No 26, Johnsons or Soldada Run, Rock Bluff
Novembr. 24 (continued) 6. p.m cloudy & cold wind. 2.50 11.83 131.52 Brought forward

Remarks.
This first part of the road is very rough.
The water in the Hole is not permanent.
Rest.
At Camp we had wood and water but no grazing.
The road is very hard and rough.
Old Camp Hudson is an abandoned post, the buildings 
are in ruins.
We crossed the Devils river about a dozen times
to day.
Pecan-spring runs into the Devils river.
Pecan-trees are growing here along the river.

68
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
182.85 Carried. 
Novembr 28. 6.20 a.m cold, drizling rain. 
Novembr. 27. rain
November. 26. 1. p.m 6.30 cloudy. rain. 0.50 19.70 162.65 Brought forward map including words Devils River Camp No 28, OLD CAMP HUDSON, Pecan Spring

Remarks.
We descended a short steep hill to the river and camped 
at n Old Mail-Station on Devils river. This is here
a beautiful stream of clear water about 2 1/2 feet deep
and 200 yards wide; there is wood, but the grazing 
is poor.
The Painted Cave is said to have been painted by In-
dians. The Creek is 2 feet deep, 30 feet wide, not per-
manent.
We passed an Old Campingground with a pool of water, 
apparently permanent; wood scarce.
The water at Yellow Banks is fit only for animals, not 
permanent; the grazing is very poor, wood scarce. The 
country is rolling, road heavy.
The water in waterhole is not permanent.
Dead men's Pass is so named from 5 men having been
killed by Indians; - they were after it found by travel-
lers.
The last part of the road is gravelly, the middle 
part heavy and hilly. -

70
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
219.18 Carried
Novembr. 29. 11. a.m 6.45. cloudy. clear. 6.65 0.75 6.50 map including words Devils River, Old Mail St. Camp No 30., Painted Cave, Old Camping Ground, Creek, Camp No 29, Yellow Banks, California Springs, Dead Mens' Pass 
Novembr. 28. (continued) 1.45 p.m 9. cold drizling rain all day. 10.43 12 182.85 Brought forward

Remarks.
This Creek is 2 1/2 feet deep and 20 feet wide, crossing
good.
An old house stands on the bank of the creek.
Road very heavy across a black muddy prairie.
The Creek is 2 feet deep and about 40 feet wide, the cros-
sing is good. The creek-bottom is muddy, but the water 
clear. The road is heavy sand.-
The Creek is about 3 feet deep and 50 feet wide; the water is 
good, some small timber on it; the crossing is good. Grazing 
is fair.
The road from San Felipe spring joins the main road, both
are very heavy and somewhat hilly. Grazing poor.
The country between the road and Rio Grande is settled 
and cultivated.
The road at first is very rough and stony, afterwards heavy 
and hilly. - It forks; the right fork goes to San Felipe spring,
the left one direct to Sycamore creek; there is no water on
the latter road.- After leaving the fork, the road runs through
a small growth of timber.-

72
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
250.77 Carried
Decembr. 1. 11. 7.05 a.m rain. 9.15 2. map including words Old House, Piedras Pintas Creek, Muddy Creek, Sycamore Creek, Camp No 31., San Felipe Spring, House an cultivated Land
Novembr, 30. 1. p.m 6 a.m windy & rainy clear. 7.61 5.09 7.74 219.18 Brought forward

Remarks
Wood and water at Camp, grazing good. The crossing of the creek is good. 
The road is rough over an undulating country. 
Elm Creek is a small stream, easily crossed, with Ranches on it. 
The Fort Duncan road turns to the right, after leaving town. Only mesquite wood can be obtained here. 
Rest (at Fort Clark)
A town of about 20 Mexican Houses close beyond Fort Clark. Between the town and the Fort is a grove of woods and a spring, from which rises Las Moras creek (running South).
A detached train of 13 wagons and 3 ambulances went from here to Fort Duncan with Company K 38" Infantry. The roads are heavy and undulating.

74
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
269.62 Carried
Decembr. 3. 12.15 p.m 9. am clear & pleasant. 3.50 7.50 map including words 3 Mile Creek, Camp No 33., Elm Creek, Mrs. Paffords Ranch, To Fort Duncan, Mexican Town, Woods, Camp no 32., FT CLARK, Las Moras Creek,
Decmbr. 3. cloudy
Decembr. 1. (continued). 1.25 p.m. rain. 7.85 250.77 Brought forward

Rio Nueces is about 60 feet wide and 2 1/2 feet deep, the bottom is clean gravel, crossing good.
The country is undulating, grazing fair.
The road forks, the right hand road goes to the lower, the left one to the upper crossing of Rio Nueces; the train took the lower road.
The road is undulating and good; it passes a pretty elevated ridge.
The Creek is small, but crossing bad.
There is timber on the Creek, grazing good.
Roads rough and part of the way heavy; a mesquite flat to the left of it.
Passed two very small streams.

76
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
293.62 Carried 
Decembr. 5. 11.15 10.05 7 a.m clear. 6.50 6. map including words Rio Nueves Ranch, Camp No 35, Spring, Wright's Ranch, Camp no 34., Turkey Creek, Paffords Ranch, Mesquite Flat, 8 Mile Creek, 6 Mile Creek
December 4. 12.30 p.m 6.30 clear cloudy and some rain  6.50 2. 3. 269.62 Brought forward

Remarks.
Rest
(waiting for detached train to return from Ft. Duncan)
Camp near the river bank; water only in holes in the river-bed, grazing on the other side of the river; wood at Camp.
The crossing of the river is very steep and over a gravel bed; the river banks are 25-30 feet deep and about 500 yards wide.
Fort Inge - road joins the main road 3 miles from Uralde The road is good, grazing poor.
Leona Creek is 1/2 mile from Uralde; it is dry most of the time.
Uralde is a small country town. - 
The road is good, goes over a mesquite prairie.

77
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
308.19 Carried
Decembr 7-11. some rain. 
Decembr. 6. 1. p.m. 6 a.m. some rain cloudy. 1.24 2.75 3.25 7.33 293.62 Brought forward map including words Camp No 36, Live Oak Grove, Rio Frio, Mail St, Road to Fort Inge, Leana Creek, Uvalde

Remarks
Wood and grazing scarce at Camp.
After crossing the road runs along the creek.
Comanche creek is a small stream, not running, contains water only in holes. -
The crossing is easy, water only in holes; - there is wood here, but grazing very poor.
Roads good.
Waterhole to the left of road in a grove of trees.
The banks of the Sabinal Creek are 50 feet wide and 15 feet high, but there is water only in holes, in the stream bed. The crossing is good.
Road good.
A small creek
Waterhole, surrounded by trees, to the left of road.

80
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route. 
327.28 Carried 
Decembr. 12. 1.15 p.m. 7.10 a.m. cloudy  2.49 4. 4. 8.60 308.19 Brought forward map including words Dinner Hole, Mesquite Flat, Boules Ranch, Blanco Creek, Sabinal Creek, Camp No 37, Comanche Ranchero Cr

Remarks
Castroville is a flourishing town. The Medina river banks are 200 feet wide and 20 feet high; the river itself is about 30 feet wide; the banks are steep, but the crossing is good.
The road is good but rough in places; about 8 miles from Castroville it commences descending a long hill.
The towns of New Fountain and Quihi are about 1 1/2 mile to the left of Camp, ( they are small places.)
Rio Hondo is 50 feet wide, banks 20 feet high, gravel bottom, no water except in holes, crossing heavy, banks steep. - There was wood & water at Camp, grazing poor. Camp 1/2 mile from the main road; it was a very heavy and wet road for the last 5 miles.
Dhanis is a small town situated in a level country. The two Creeks are very small, water scarce; there is wood, but grazing poor; - roads good. -

82
Date. Hour. Weathr Dist. Route.
360.51 Carried
Decembr. 14. 10.30 7 a.m clear. 11.26 map including words Castroville, Medina River, TO Quihi, Camp No 38., Rio Hondo, Dhanis Prarie, Kinsloe's Prarie, Parkers Cr, Dhanis, Seco Creek
Decembr. 13. 1.30 p.m. 6.30 a.m cloudy 0.50 8.55 4. 8.92 327.28 Brought forward

Remarks
to San Antonio
The roads were heavy over mesquite-prairie, very rough. Grazing fair; water and wood in places, but the latter is scarce.
Leon Creek is a small stream & easily crossed; wood scarce. The grazing fair. Houses on the creek, roads heavy over mesquite country. 
From the top of the ridge between Leon & Media Creek the town of San Antonio can be seen.
_________________________________________________________
Camped to the left of road in a mesquite flat. Media creek is a small stream 3 feet wide and 6 inches deep. Wood at Camp, grazing good, roads and undulating. 
San Lucas springs are permanent.
Adams Ranch on top of a hill.
Grazing fair, some timber in the country.
The roads are heavy, passing through mesquite prairie.

Total 385.35 Miles fron Fr Stockton
Decembr. 15. 11.10 8.35 7 a.m clear & cold. 7.48 4.16 map including words SAN ANTONIO, Leon Creek, Camp. No 39, Adam's Ranch, San Lucas Spring, Road to Laredo, Gen Wool's Crossing
Decembr. 14. (continued.) 2.30 p.m. 12.50 clear. 5.01 8.19. 360.57 Brought forward
